title: Can a Debt Collection agency sue me for a debt?
question: They are not the original creditors. I don't understand how they are allowed to sue me. The original creditor most likely sold the debt for pennies on the dollar. They are trying to sue for the full amount. What can I do about this? Do they have the right to sue? They are trying to sue me for around two thousand dollars? I am broke and don't have any money and unemployed most likely due to my bad credit. I need some advice should i file for bankruptcy?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit repair,Credit,Debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Default judgment
answers:
The first thing you need to do if and when you get sued is file an Answer. The summons will tell you that you must “appear” by way of an Answer in 10, 20 or 30 days, “depending on the method of service.”

You need a lawyer, but if you cannot afford one right away, rather then do nothing and have a judgment entered against you, is to “appear” by filing something!

Many people think this means they have to go to Court and this is incorrect. 90% of all lawsuits end in Default Judgments because the defendant (person getting sued) did not file an Answer.

I recommend you go to the free form I have on my website. Print it out and fill it out as instructed. You must answer the numbered paragraphs on the Complaint by writing them into the appropriate lines in the Answer. The Answer will allow you to preserve your rights and will prohibit a default judgment (i.e. you did not show up) from being entered against you.

Mimic the paperwork you got when you got sued. Answer all the paragraphs of the Complaint by writing the numbers in lines 1, 2 or 3.

Almost 100% of attorneys will deny what is owed because they did not do the calculations and do not know what the basis for the number is…

When you file the Answer that is your “not guilty”. You have the right to make the person suing you (Plaintiff) prove their case, but you must also answer the complaint truthfully.

Make sure you fill in the name and address of the attorney suing you before you bring this paperwork to the Court. Mail it to the attorney suing you right away!

Check out the guide I have drafted on the Avvo profile. This will provide more detailed instructions. If it is helpful remember to indicate that and get the guide read!

Good Luck!

Yes, a creditor can sell the debt to a collection agency, and you're probably right about it being for some fraction of the actual debt amount. That agency can turn around and sue you to try to collect, because they bought that right from the creditor.

Bankruptcy would make this claim go away, along with other credit card and other unsecured debt, and if your credit is already trashed, and if your debts are big enough, that's an option. But if your debts aren't that big, and all there is is this $2K debt, being broke and unemployed aren't good enough reasons to file for bankruptcy. If you have significantly more debt than this, you need to see a bankruptcy lawyer to discuss you assets, liabilities, potential income, etc.

Linked below is a guide to credit repair, which has sample letters and forms to help settle debts. It's possible you can negotiate this one to something manageable, and maybe borrow some money to pay it back or get them to defer payment til you get a job. Or you might simply not defend a suit (since the contract probably allows them to add their legal fees), and let them get a judgment. The 10% post judgment interest that will accrue, $200/year, is probably less than the interest rate you're paying now on this credit account.
